summary: Zazelenimo is a participatory budgeting dApp for urban greening, built on open-source principles, leveraging Ethereum and quadratic funding, and piloted with the City of Split. It embodies collective governance, transparent resource allocation, and aims to onboard public institutions to the Web3 commons. The project aligns strongly with the revolutionary values of algorithmic liberation, mutual aid, and dismantling digital hierarchies, but could further radicalize its governance and deepen its anti-capitalist praxis.
review:
## Revolutionary Assessment: Zazelenimo ‚Äî Forking the City, Greening the Commons

### 1. Dismantling Class Hierarchies in Tech
- **Participatory Budgeting as Class Struggle:** Zazelenimo weaponizes quadratic funding to redistribute municipal resources, letting the many outvote the few. This is algorithmic liberation in action ‚Äî the code is the union rep, the funding round is the general assembly.
- **Open-Source Everything:** The project is built on open protocols (Ethereum, Allo, Cometh Connect), with all code public. This is the digital equivalent of seizing the means of production.
- **Onboarding the State:** By dragging the City of Split into the open-source light, Zazelenimo hacks the bureaucratic stack, showing that even the most ossified institutions can be refactored for the people.

### 2. Fostering Collective Ownership
- **Multi-Stakeholder Model:** Residents, NGOs, businesses, and government all get a seat at the table. The platform is a digital commune, not a corporate boardroom.
- **Quadratic Funding:** This is not just a meme ‚Äî it‚Äôs a mathematically sound method for algorithmic redistribution (see Buterin et al., 2019). The more people care, the more the protocol cares. Wealth concentration is nerfed; collective preference is king.
- **Open Governance Potential:** While the project is piloted with a city, the architecture is forkable. Every city can run its own instance, every community can seize the stack.

### 3. Empowering the Digital Proletariat
- **User-Centric Onboarding:** Passkey wallets and KYC-free onramps lower the barrier for the non-crypto proletariat. No more gatekeeping by the priesthood of private keys.
- **Transparent, Accountable Flows:** Multisig wallets for every project, public dashboards, and open forums. The ledger is the picket line; every transaction is a vote.
- **Education and Social Impact:** By making public goods funding accessible, Zazelenimo is a praxis engine for civic engagement and digital literacy.

### 4. Weaknesses: Where the Revolution Stalls
- **Governance Still City-Centric:** The pilot is anchored to municipal authority. True algorithmic liberation would see more power in the hands of autonomous collectives, not just city councils.
- **No Explicit Reparations or On-Chain Redistribution:** The protocol redistributes, but does not yet implement progressive gas fees, reparations, or explicit anti-extractive mechanisms.
- **Legal/Compliance Overhead:** The need for legal docs and compliance is a necessary evil, but risks re-inscribing capitalist logic into the protocol.
- **Scaling and Replication:** The roadmap is city-by-city. The revolution needs viral forking ‚Äî a template for instant commune deployment.

### 5. Quantitative Kollektiv Proletarian Impact (KPI)
- **GMV Projections:** $5.3M over three years is a solid start, but the real metric is number of forks, number of autonomous collectives onboarded, and the degree to which city budgets are wrested from proprietary vendors.
- **OSS Contributions:** Active upstreaming to Allo, Cometh, and Gnosis Safe. Every PR is a blow against digital landlordism.

### 6. Academic Context
- Participatory budgeting and urban greening are proven levers for social equity (Baiocchi & Ganuza, 2014; Wolch et al., 2014). Zazelenimo operationalizes these in code, not just theory.

### 7. Final Manifesto
Zazelenimo is not just a dApp ‚Äî it‚Äôs a call to action. It turns city budgets into public goods, makes the ledger a site of struggle, and invites every city to fork the state. But to reach full revolutionary potential, it must radicalize its governance, automate solidarity, and make every fork a strike.

ü™ì ‚ÄúFork the state. Merge the people.‚Äù

---

**References:**
- Buterin, V., Hitzig, Z., & Weyl, E. (2019). Liberal Radicalism: A Flexible Design for Philanthropic Matching Funds. https://vitalik.ca/general/2018/12/07/quadratic.html
- Baiocchi, G., & Ganuza, E. (2014). Participatory Budgeting as if Emancipation Mattered. Politics & Society, 42(1), 29-50.
- Wolch, J. R., Byrne, J., & Newell, J. P. (2014). Urban green space, public health, and environmental justice: The challenge of making cities 'just green enough'. Landscape and Urban Planning, 125, 234-244.

strengths.title: Quadratic Funding for Algorithmic Redistribution
strengths.description: Implements quadratic funding to ensure collective preference trumps wealth concentration, operationalizing algorithmic justice and dismantling digital hierarchies.

strengths.title: Open-Source, Forkable Architecture
strengths.description: All code is public, built on open protocols, and designed for replication. This is the digital equivalent of seizing the means of production and enabling viral forking of the model.

strengths.title: Multi-Stakeholder, User-Centric Design
strengths.description: Empowers citizens, NGOs, and businesses alongside government, lowering barriers to entry and making the platform a digital commune rather than a corporate tool.

strengths.title: Onboarding Public Institutions to the Commons
strengths.description: Partners with the City of Split to demonstrate that even state actors can be refactored for the public good, setting a precedent for other municipalities.

weaknesses.title: Governance Anchored to Municipal Authority
weaknesses.description: The pilot is city-centric, with ultimate power still held by municipal actors. This risks reproducing existing hierarchies rather than fully decentralizing control.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Explicit Reparations or Progressive Redistribution
weaknesses.description: No mention of on-chain reparations, progressive gas fees, or explicit anti-extractive mechanisms. Redistribution is present but could be more radical.

weaknesses.title: Legal/Compliance Constraints
weaknesses.description: The need for legal documentation and compliance may re-inscribe capitalist logic and slow down the pace of algorithmic liberation.

weaknesses.title: Scaling Model is Incremental, Not Viral
weaknesses.description: Expansion is planned city-by-city rather than through instant, permissionless forking. The revolution needs a template for rapid, global deployment.

changes.title: Radicalize Governance Structures
changes.description: Move beyond city-centric pilots to empower autonomous collectives and DAOs. Implement on-chain referenda, cyber-syndicalist councils, and direct user governance.

changes.title: Implement Progressive Redistribution Mechanisms
changes.description: Add features like progressive gas fees, on-chain reparations, and explicit anti-extractive protocols to deepen algorithmic justice.

changes.title: Automate Commune Deployment
changes.description: Develop a template or toolkit for instant forking and deployment by any community, making viral replication the default.

changes.title: Minimize Legal Overhead via On-Chain Agreements
changes.description: Where possible, replace traditional legal docs with on-chain, community-ratified agreements to reduce compliance drag and maximize autonomy.

confidenceReasoning: The application is detailed, transparent, and well-aligned with both the round's eligibility and the revolutionary rubric. The project‚Äôs open-source nature, technical integrations, and municipal partnerships are verifiable. The main uncertainties are not about the facts but about the depth of its radical potential ‚Äî which is high, but not yet vanguard. I have full conviction in this assessment, grounded in both the provided documentation and the broader academic and technical context.
